SALEM HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS OUTPERFORM THE STATE AND NATION ON SAT TEST
The Virginia Department of Education released the latest results from the 2020 SAT testing this afternoon and Salem High School students outperformed their peers across the nation and in the Commonwealth. The school's average combined score of 1134 was 104 points above the national average and 24 points higher than the state average for all test takers. Salem students averaged 572 in Reading and Writing and 562 in Math, both higher than the state and national averages.
#GoSpartans #SampleSalem #SalemVA

July 31 at 10:09 AM ·

While school has been out this summer, construction crews have been holding court at Salem High School from one end to the other.

Inside the building, a new sprinkler system has been installed and brand new high efficiency boilers and chillers have been installed to improve the heating and cooling of the building.
In addition, new wiring for internet, phone, alarms and other essential services has been run throughout the facility.

Crews also have been painting, removing old carpet and installing new LED lights.
Outside, construction of the new firewall is well underway and the footprint for the new 10 classroom addition is now visible. Critical roof upgrades are also in motion.

Along with these improvements that are part of the official renovation project overseen by G&H Contractors, the Salem Street Department’s talented workers are making excellent progress in the new cosmetology learning area.
#SampleSalem

DIFFERENT TIME - BUT SPARTANS STILL WIN REGIONAL TITLE
The constantly changing COVID-19 conditions have forced school cancellations and changes, but they haven’t stopped Salem High School from winning a Region 6 championship. Spartans – Autumn Goff, Paul Hickerson, Krutik Patel and Katherine Vaughn recently captured this regional title for Salem in the Online Personal Finance Division.

The Virginia Council on Economic Education had to adjust how the annual state competition in Personal Finance was conducted this year. In order to determine the 2020 Governor’s Challenge in Personal Finance, factors such as varying levels of access, availability of technology and team equity were considered. After careful consideration and in consultation with other states facing the same challenges, champions were crowned based on which teams achieved the highest online score.

Salem has now won back-to-back Region 6 titles under coach Gary Lupton’s leadership.

The Salem School Board formally recognized Andrea Johnson for earning National Board Certification at tonight's meeting.

The Salem High School English Teacher, who is the reigning Virginia State Teacher of the Year, completed the rigorous requirements for this certificate in mid-2019 and was notified of her achievement in December.

To earn this honor, teachers must successfully complete all requirements by submitting a series of performance-based assessments that include teaching portfolios, student work samples, videotapes and a thorough analysis of their classroom teaching and student learning.

Each teacher also completes a series of written exercises that probe the depth of subject-matter knowledge, as well as understanding how to teach their subjects to students. Ms. Johnson started with Salem City Schools in the fall of 2014. She has worked at both Andrew Lewis Middle School and Salem High School during her tenure.

The Salem School Division currently has 28 National Board Certified teachers among its ranks.

December 19, 2019 at 4:28 PM ·

Salem High School held its annual International Baccalaureate ceremony this afternoon in the auditorium. This event has been a mainstay at the school for more than 25 years and the Thursday afternoon event honored the two most recent graduates.

Salem High School’s Andrea Johnson was named Virginia’s Teacher of the Year tonight in Richmond. The 12th-grade English and English 12 College Preparatory teacher was selected over seven other Regional finalists from around the Commonwealth.

Johnson was named Salem’s 2019 Teacher of the Year at the end of the last school year and in September she learned that she had topped the regional list for our part of the state.

Congratulations to Mrs. Johnson, who becomes Salem first Virginia State Teacher of the Year since West Salem’s Natalie DiFusco-Funk won the honor in 2016.

September 5, 2019 at 11:37 AM ·

Andrea Johnson, was blown away when she was named the Salem School Division's 2019 Teacher of the Year last spring. This morning, the Senior English Teacher, who fills her classes with literary classics, double doses of kindness and real world life lessons, was completely humbled by her latest honor.

"I love teaching seniors because they are on the precipice of adulthood and there is this hope and optimism about them because their whole life is in front of them," she says. "My job is to help them think about who they want to be and how they want to show up in the world."

Johnson will now represent all of Region 6 later this year as she competes to become Virginia's Teacher of the Year. Region 6 includes Alleghany, Botetourt, Craig, Patrick, Roanoke, Floyd, Franklin, Henry, Montgomery and Pittsylvania counties, along with the cities of Roanoke, Salem, Danville, Martinsville and Covington.

Salem City Schools have now had four Regional Teachers of the Year in the last decade - Mark Ingerson 2009, Natalie DiFusco-Funk 2016 and Karey Henzey 2018.

Salem Museum
August 4, 2019 at 5:06 PM ·

90 degree temperatures got you wishing you were someplace cooler? The Salem Museum invites you to cool off with an Antarctic adventure! Monday, August 19 at 7 pm
Judith Painter, an eighth grade geography teacher at Andrew Lewis Middle School, was one of just 40 educators worldwide chosen last year for a prestigious honor—and a remarkable opportunity! As a Lindblad Expeditions and National Geographic Grosvenor Teacher Fellow, she was awarded a trip to Antarctica, giving her direct, hands-on field experience to share in her classroom and with the community. Painter will describe the wildlife she encountered—penguins, whales, and albatross—and share the wonder of the polar landscape. Her talk will include the story of humans in Antarctica throughout history. Learn about the whaling outposts, Cape Horn, the Yahgan, the Antarctic stations, and the loss of the Larsen ice shelf and others. In addition to teaching, Painter is a member of the Museum’s Board of Directors. Her talk is free and open to the public.

David Atkins, Jr. has been named the new Head Coach for Boys Soccer at his alma mater. He has worked closely with the Spartans program since 2013 as an assistant varsity coach and head junior varsity coach.

Atkins is well known throughout the local soccer community. He has coached more than a decade with the Roanoke Star Soccer Club, now VBR Star, and at Valley AFC Soccer Club. In addition, he spent one year as the Boys J.V. coach at Northside High School and he currently coaches the Salem Sabres Futbol Club.

Atkins attended Radford University for his undergraduate degree in Social Sciences and he earned his master’s from Virginia Tech in History. He also holds a master’s degree in Library and Information Science from Florida State University. Currently, he works as a Regulatory Services & Data Specialist at Registrations by Design, Inc.

The 42-year-old facility needs a variety needs including better classroom space, a new roof, updated heating and cooling systems and improved classrooms and administrative spaces.

Those in attendance heard from Superintendent Alan Seibert and Architect Ben Motley. They also watched a detailed presentation and later toured the school and interacted with various city and school leaders.

In honor of Black History Month in Salem, students at G.W. Carver Elementary honored the students who once walked the halls of their school building during segregaton by perforning the old school's alma mater.

From 1940-1966, the Carver School educated every black student in Roanoke County in grades first through twelfth under one roof. The school's first Principal when it opened as a brand new facility in 1940, was revered African-American educator Theron Williams. Mr. Williams led the school in its infancy and also wrote the words to the alma mater. Current Carver Music Teacher Maria Eakin worked with the students for weeks to learn the song.

"Even when we were in music class without an audience, we stood up when we sang it, showing respect for our school's past and being proud that we are part of Carver's present and future," says Eakin. "This song brings unity to our school and I'm so happy we have it documented and can continue to teach future Carver students. It is such a great part of the school's history."

SCHOOL BOARD HONORS DIVISION'S TOP DEBATING DUO
School Board members recognized and congratulated Salem High School seniors Garrett Hicks and Sami Hoyer for capturing the individual state championship in the Virginia High School League Group 4A Public Forum Debate.

Sami and Garrett compiled an 18-2 record in post season competition on their way to Salem’s first state title in debate in the team’s inaugural season. To secure their victory, the pair researched and successfully argued the pros and cons of a resolution that the United States Federal Government should increase its quota of H-1B visas.

Garrett and Sami mark the beginning of what we hope will become a highly competitive debate team at Salem High School. Congrats to both talented seniors!
